awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Collaborative Research: Robust High Order Meshing and Analysis for Design Pipeline Automation
awd_abstract_narration:
The simulation of many real-world phenomena (such as elastoplastic deformations, sound propagation, and heat diffusion) relies on an explicit discretization of the space, which allows storage of physical quantities and performance of computations upon them. However, the Computer Aided Design (CAD) tools used to design shapes rely on a different discretization, usually a collection of disconnected high-order polynomial patches, which cannot be used in simulations. It is thus necessary to convert CAD models into simulation meshes, a procedure that can introduce geometric errors due to the use of linear elements and requires manual interaction, which limits its use to high-end applications.  This research will develop a novel, automatic approach to tackle this conversion "exactly" by using high order elements, thereby avoiding unnecessary geometric approximations. The project will study high-order mesh generation and simulation as a single problem, building upon recent advances in robust linear meshing and developing new finite element method techniques that will allow non-expert users to benefit from simulation at a fraction of the time and cost currently needed to accomplish that task, which in turn will open the doors to new applications in medicine and digital fabrication. The project will involve extensive testing of the developed algorithms on a large collection of real-world CAD models. Both the data collected during this project and the reference implementation of the algorithms will be released in the public domain to foster adoption of the new technique as well as future research in this direction.

The goal of this project is to develop a robust meshing pipeline that generates curvilinear elements that can reproduce both CAD models and subdivision surfaces with high fidelity, uses a direct measure of approximation errors, leading to coarse meshes that are designed to match the simulation accuracy required by applications, and can robustly and automatically process large collections of real-world CAD models. For interactive applications, the combination of the generated curved elements and the new error estimate will lead to extremely coarse models ideal for fast simulation. In CAD settings, it will for the first time enable precise modeling of complex scenarios such as the driving of a screw or the simulations of the stress concentration on fillets. The approach will close the gap between design tools, providing an automatic conversion of curved geometry to analysis-suitable curved meshes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
High-order meshes are spatial discretizations where cells with curved faces are used to represent complex 3D geometry accurately. These spatial discretizations have a wide range of uses, from modeling CAD objects for manufacturing, simulating biomedical models, or accurately representing the movement of deformable robots.

 

In this project, we designed and realized an algorithmic approach to 1. convert existing geometries into coarse, high-order tetrahedral meshes; 2. detect intersections and collisions present in these meshes either statically or as they deform; 3. simulate elastodynamic systems with contact and friction forces. 

 

The high-order meshing approach is based on a novel shell construction that allows for a reduction of the high-order meshing problem to a much simpler linear problem. The construction supports sharp features and low-quality input meshes, making it suitable for many tasks in life science, engineering, and computer graphics.

 

We introduced two methods for curved collision detection: the first one is exact and supports arbitrary geometries and trajectories, making it ideal for engineering applications where a correct answer is paramount. The second one is conservative instead of exact and very efficient, making it a drop-in replacement over traditional piece-wise linear collision detection methods.

 

Finally, we developed an elastodynamic simulation algorithm supporting contact and friction forces, which exploits the curved meshes to increase the efficiency and accuracy of the displacement computation. We show that our approach is one order of magnitude faster than competing linear approaches for a similar accuracy target.

 

To foster the adoption of our approach and to ensure reproducibility of our results, we released open-source projects for all three major contributions with a flexible open-source license. We also collected both a 2D and a 3D dataset of curved geometries, which we used to evaluate our algorithms. The TriWild dataset is composed of 20 thousand SVG files, while the 3D Bichon dataset is composed of 10 thousand 3D meshes. We converted these models into high-order 2D and 3D meshes directly suitable for finite element analysis — these datasets are 3 orders of magnitude larger than the existing collection of curved meshes. We expect that these two datasets will become a staple in evaluating the performance and reliability of curved meshing and simulation approaches.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/19/2023
Modified by: Daniele Panozzo
